instruction: How were the machine learning models used to establish relationships between soil spectral responses and the contents of Co and Ni in the samples in the past study?
Output:
In the past study, three machine learning (ML) techniques, namely extreme gradient boosting (EGB), random forest (RF), and support vector regression (SVR), were utilized to establish relationships between soil spectral responses and the contents of cobalt (Co) and nickel (Ni) in the samples. The ML models were trained using the spectral data obtained from visible-near-infrared-shortwave infrared (VNIR-SWIR) reflectance spectroscopy of the soil samples collected from the Sarcheshmeh copper mine waste dump surface in Iran.

The ML models were developed based on the spectral data and the corresponding Co and Ni contents of the samples. The models were trained to learn the patterns and relationships between the spectral responses and the concentrations of Co and Ni. The goal was to create models that could accurately predict the Co and Ni contents of new soil samples based on their spectral responses.

To optimize the performance of the ML models, the first derivative (FD) spectra of the soil samples were used. The FD spectra provide enhanced spectral features and can improve the accuracy of the predictions. The ML models were evaluated based on their prediction accuracies, which were measured using the root mean square error of prediction (RMSEp) values.

instruction: Can VNIR-SWIR reflectance spectroscopy be considered a superior alternative technique for quantifying the contents of cobalt and nickel in soil samples compared to traditional methods?
Output:
VNIR-SWIR reflectance spectroscopy shows promise as an alternative technique for quantifying the contents of cobalt (Co) and nickel (Ni) in soil samples. The past study investigated the capability of VNIR-SWIR spectroscopy to quantify the contents of Co and Ni in soil samples collected from a copper mine waste dump surface in Iran. Three machine learning techniques (extreme gradient boosting, random forest, and support vector regression) were used to establish relationships between soil spectral responses and Co and Ni contents.

The results showed that the best prediction accuracies were obtained using the models developed on the first derivative spectra. The root mean square error of prediction (RMSEp) values for Co ranged from 7.82 to 9.22 mg/kg, and for Ni ranged from 9.88 to 11.02 mg/kg, depending on the machine learning algorithm used. The spatial variability maps of the elements also showed relatively similar patterns between observed and predicted values.

Furthermore, the past study revealed that the most important wavelengths for Co and Ni prediction were those related to iron oxides/hydroxides and clay minerals, which are key soil properties controlling their speciation.
